title: Re: GNU compiler
content:
MinGW if you just want the compiler, as opposed to the entire linux shell

then add the /bin/ folder (where you installed MinGW) to your path

finally, to compile, in the command line and appropriate directory type "g++ file.cpp -o fileName" in order for the compiled program to be fileName.exe (or "j++" or "gcc" i think). (This is the same as in GNU.)

From what I gather, installing GNU is much more arduous.[quote]Quote:[hr]Just remember that this is the year of the elite devil.

1337 + 666 = 2003[hr][/quote]

title: Re: GNU compiler
content:
Yes. Just keep in mind that you must install g++ to be able to compile C++ programs, as gcc only does C by its own AFAIK.

MinGW's installer offers you the possibility to select what tools you want to install.

After that, everything should be easy if you have experience with makefiles. Just do make. I think there are even Integrated Development Environments for MinGW, but I don't recall specific names atm.

I think you can even use it along with Visual C++ if you tweak the project settings to use a compiler other than MS's included one. IIRC that is possible.------------------------------

title: Re: GNU compiler
content:
if you're using windows, just download bloodshed c++. The compiler is mingw. It comes with quite a decent gui as well, so you don't have to use the command line to compile your code.

It has support for c/c++ and im sure more languages. I used it about 4 years ago in college for a c++ course i took and it worked quite well for what i needed to do.

If you still want to use mingw via the command line, then i suggest you look at reading the documentation. You can't just expect people to tell you how to use it as it does take a bit of time getting used to especially if you've never worked with command line before.

[img]http://www.cocoanut.org/images/cocoa-forum.png[/img]

[url=http://www.cocoanut.org]www.cocoanut.org[/url]

title: Re: GNU compiler
content:
MinGW has become rather complex with all those modules. I remember it being a lot simpler to acquire the files for installing a CLI-only configuration a few years ago. The installation's usually fairly straightforward, finding the files is confusing.

I second Blue's suggestion. Grab Dev-C++. You'll have access to a nice IDE and still be able to use MinGW from the command line. Plus it has a good repository of libraries you can install fairly easily from within the program.

Good luck.

title: Re: GNU compiler
content:
Or get Code::Blocks, which is actually still updated and improved on, and it uses the same devpacks repository. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img]

Installing MinGW should be a piece ofcake, btw. Download the installer, install, done. Code::Blocks and Dev-C++ should automatically pick it up.____________

title: Re: Dev-C++
content:
Write a plain DOS-style .bat file such as:
[pre] @echo off<name and path of the generated program>pause[/pre]

And that solves it. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

(I suppose dev-C++ allows you to set the path to the "program" to be launched when you launch your project. At least Visual C++, Eclipse, most debuggers and GNU Emacs do.)------------------------------
